questions.text: 1. Regarding different grades of binocular single vision. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Figure 1 describes simultaneous macular perception and figure 2 describes fusion
Figure 1 describes fusion and figure 2 describes simultaneous macular perception
Figure 1 describes stereopsis and figure 2 describes simultaneous macular perception
Figure 1 describes simulataneous macular perception and figure 2 describes steropsis

questions.solution:
The image depicts binocular vision. Figure 1 describes simultaneous macular perception, and Figure 2 describes fusion.

When a normal individual fixes their visual attention on an object of regard, the image is formed on the fovea of both eyes separately, but the individual perceives a single image. The visual axes of the two eyes intersect at the point of fixation. The images are aligned by the fusion reflex and combined by binocular responsive cells in the visual cortex. This is known as binocular single vision. It is a conditioned reflex that is not present since birth but is acquired during the initial months and is completed during the first few years of development, called the critical period of visual development. 

It has 3 grades:

* Simultaneous perception

* Fusion

* Stereopsis

Prerequisites for the development of binocular single vision are:

* Motor mechanism- Straight eyes starting from the neonatal period, with precise coordination for all directions of gaze

* Sensory mechanism- Reasonably clear vision in both eyes so that similar images are presented to each retina

* Mental process- Ability of the visual cortex to promote binocular single vision 

The field of binocular single vision can be tested using Goldmann perimetry, a tangent screen, or a Hess chart. It usually measures about 45° to 50° from the fixation point, except on the nasal side. It represents the parts of the visual field of each eye that overlap, and where bifoveal fusion of the objects occurs.



Pearl PM1014: Grades of binocular vision

I - Simultaneous perception                       

* Ability to see two dissimilar objects simultaneously

II - Fusion

* Ability to superimpose two incomplete but similar images

III - Stereopsis

* Ability to perceive depth

questions.text: 2. A patient with bullous keratopathy has corneal guttata in the other eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral progressive endothelial cell loss. It is usually seen in middle age and is more common in women, with a slightly increased prevalence in patients with glaucoma. It is mostly inherited sporadically, with occasional autosomal dominant inheritance. Mutations in the COL8A2 and TCF4 genes have been noted. 

There is a gradual blurring of vision, more commonly in the morning, due to corneal oedema. There is development of guttata, which are excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular microscopy). 

Signs of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy are:

* Cornea guttata, which are irregular warts or excrescences on the Descemet membrane secreted by abnormal endothelial cells 

* Subtle corneal endothelial radial lines

* Specular reflection shows tiny dark spots caused by disruption of the regular endothelial layer. It progresses to a ‘beaten metal’ appearance

* Central stromal oedema 

* Epithelial oedema develops in more advanced cases, with the formation of microcysts and bullae that cause discomfort

* Bullous keratopathy 

* Rupture of bullae associated with marked acute pain secondary to the exposure of nerve fibres.

* Subepithelial scarring and peripheral vascularisation in longstanding cases

Conservative treatment includes topical sodium chloride 5% drops or ointment, reduction of IOP and use of a hair dryer for corneal dehydration. Use of bandage contact lenses, cycloplegics, antibiotic ointment and lubricants helps to treat ruptured bullae.

Posterior lamellar keratoplasty and penetrating keratoplasty are useful. A topical Rho-kinase inhibitor with prior transcorneal endothelial cryotherapy seems to stimulate endothelial cell proliferation and improve function.

Corneal endothelium on specular microscopy, as shown below-



Light microscopic appearance of the corneal endothelium, Descemet membrane, and the adjacent corneal stroma showing guttae is shown below.



Other options:

Option A: Trachoma presents with conjunctivitis associated with a mucopurulent discharge.

Option B: Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism.

Option D: Herpes keratitis presents with redness, photophobia, watering, blurred vision and ulcers, which can lead to corneal scarring.

Pearl PM0711: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

* Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)

* Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy

* Meesman’s dystrophy

* Lisch’s epithelial dystrophy

* Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy

Bowman’s Membrane

* Reis Buckler’s dystrophy

* Thiel-Behnke corneal dystrophy

* Grayson-Wilbrandt corneal dystrophy

Stromal Corneal Dystrophies

* Lattice corneal dystrophy

* Granular dystrophy

* Macular corneal dystrophy

* Schnyder corneal dystrophy

* Fleck corneal dystrophy

* Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy

* Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois

Descemet membrane and Endothelial corneal dystrophy

* Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy

* Posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD)

* Congenital hereditary endothelial

* X-linked endothelial corneal dystrophy

The given image shows an Intracorneal stromal ring segment that is used in the treatment of Keratoconus.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as a characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism.

Intracorneal stromal ring segment helps to flatten the cornea, improves vision and facilitates contact lens tolerance in advanced cases of keratoconus.

Other treatment methods for keratoconus are:

* Spectacle correction

* Rigid gas-permeable contact lens

* Corneal collagen cross-linking - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitise the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light

* Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty and penetrating keratoplasty

Pearl PM2451: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

* Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze  Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

* Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.

* Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.

* Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.

* Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.

* Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.

* Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

* Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.

* Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Pearl PM0783: Vogt's striae



The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

* Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

* It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.

* It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.

* The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: 4. A 65-year-old male came with complaints of a decrease in vision. There were white deposits on the anterior lens surface, seen during slit lamp examination. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a decrease in vision and the image showing white deposits on the anterior lens surface suggests the diagnosis to be pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.

The deposition of this exfoliative material occurs on the iris, ciliary region, and lens capsule. They appear as flakes on the anterior lens capsule and the edge of the iris. There is a radially indented peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material, separated by a clear zone maintained by pupillary abrasion. Pupillary dilation helps in visualising this peripheral capsular deposition.

The material can get collected in the anterior chamber angle and impede the aqueous humour drainage, thus developing secondary open-angle glaucoma. Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen. Treatment involves laser trabeculoplasty to remove this material deposition.

Other options

Option A: Iritis with pupillary deposits can be seen in uveitis, which usually presents with ocular pain and redness.

Option B: Glaucomflecken with acute angle closure glaucoma presents as focal opacification of the lens due to epithelial cell necrosis. 

Option C: Anterior capsule opacification can occur postoperatively in cataract surgeries.

questions.text: 5. Which of the following statements regarding orbital cellulitis is true:

choices.text: Inflammation is restricted anterior to the oribtal wall
Topical broad spectrum antibiotics are the first line of management
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups
Patient presents with proptosis, blurring of vision, normal pupillary and ocular movement

questions.solution:
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups is the correct statement.

Orbital cellulitis is the most frequent acute complication of ethmoid sinusitis. The lamina papyracea forms part of the medial wall of the orbit, is paper-thin and perforated by numerous foramina for nerves and blood vessels. Hence, ethmoid sinusitis frequently leads to orbital cellulitis.

It can present in the following 5 stages:

Chandler–Hubert classification
Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3  Stage 4  Stage 5

Preseptal cellulitis  

Postseptal cellulitis or orbital cellulitis without abscess (Option A)

Subperiosteal abscess

Orbital abscess

Cavernous sinus thrombosis/abscess

Inflammation does not extend beyond the orbital septum (where the medial orbital periosteal reflection attaches to the medial eyelid at the tarsal plate).

Inflammation extends into the tissues of the orbit.

There is abscess formation deep to the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically at the lamina papyracea from ethmoid sinusitis.

There is abscess formation within the orbit which has breached the periosteum.

The inflammatory process has extended into the cavernous sinus which thromboses and may progress to abscess formation.


Orbital cellulitis presents with extensive swelling of the lids with chemosis. There is proptosis of the eye and its mobility is impaired resulting in diplopia. Pain is severe and increases by movement of the eye (Option D).

CT/MRI should be done to delineate the extent of infection. Intravenous treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics is the the first line of management (Option B).

questions.text: 6. A 15-year-old girl came with painless swelling, gradually progressed over one year. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with painless swelling, gradually progressing over one year, and the given image suggest the most probable diagnosis to be a dermoid cyst.

A dermoid cyst is a choristoma that occurs due to the displacement of ectoderm to a subcutaneous location along embryonic lines of closure. They are lined by keratinised stratified squamous epithelium, have a fibrous wall and contain dermal appendages such as sweat glands, sebaceous glands and hair follicles.

They can be superficial, located anterior to the orbital septum or deep, located posterior to the orbital septum. A superficial orbital dermoid cyst presents in infancy with a painless nodule in the superotemporal and occasionally in the superonasal part of the orbit. It is mobile under the skin but is usually attached to the adjacent periosteum, and the posterior margins are easily palpable.

A deep dermoid cyst presents in adolescence or adult life with a gradually increasing proptosis of the eye or acutely with an inflamed orbit due to rupture. It has indistinct posterior margins. Imaging is done to rule out dumb-bell or subperiosteal extension. Superficial dermoid cyst shows a well-circumscribed heterogeneous cystic lesion, while deep cyst shows a well-circumscribed lesion that may be associated with bony defects or may extend into the inferotemporal fossa or intracranially.

A dermoid cyst is treated by excision in toto. Care must be taken to prevent the leaking of keratin into the surrounding tissue because it can result in severe granulomatous inflammation.

Other options:

Option A: Lacrimal gland mass presents as a smooth, firm, non-tender, painless, slowly progressive mass in the superolateral eyelid mass leading to proptosis with inferonasal dystopia. It is usually seen in older age groups.

Option B: Hemangioma that presents as a proptosis is located deeper, while the superficial ones present as a red-coloured cutaneous lesion.

Option C: Osteoma is a palpable bony nodule, but does not usually present in the eye.
